summary: the cause of pneumonia in intensive care units remains unknown in nearly 30% of cases despite extensive microbiological investigations. microorganisms previously identified include bacteria, fungi and viruses for which the role in the observed pathology is not clear. 185 episodes of ICU pneumonia and 25 control cases were studied using 16S rDNA gene amplification followed by cloning and sequencing. in preliminary results, we have reported the likely frequency of Tropheryma whipplei and the occurrence of vegetable DNA in pneumonia patients [12], [13]. results Bacterial microbiota as evaluated by 16S rDNA Molecular assays were positive for at least one bacterium for 129 out of 185 bronchoalveolar lavage samples from patients with pneumonia as well as from 13 out of 25 from control individuals. ne libraries of controls identified 38 species belonging to 4 different phyla. gram-negative bacilli, gram-positive cocci, and anaerobic bacteria from oropharyngeal flora were the most frequent bacteria identified. 51 strictly anaerobic bacteria were found in patients versus 17 anaerobic bacteria found in controls.
